issues.text: whether the appellant is guilty of the offence under section 302 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: The short question which arises for determination in this appeal is whether the appellant is guilty of the offence under section 302 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code. So far as this question is concerned, we find that it is in the evidence of Nasir Khan

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence of PW Nasir Khan shows Nawab Ali did not re-enter the house; police found him absent; no proof of timing of strangulation.

arguments.claim: Nawab Ali denied the prosecution allegations about his complicity and stated that he had been falsely involved due to enmity with Puttan Khan.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial Nawab Ali appellant, with whom we are concerned, denied the prosecution allegations about his complicity and stated that he had been falsely involved in this case because of enmity with Puttan Khan.

arguments.claim: The trial court and High Court accepted the prosecution case that appellant was guilty under section 302 read with section 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court and the High Court accepted the prosecution case and convicted the accused as above.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ly after he had left the house- of Mohd. Shafi and had thus ceased to be a member of the unlawful assembly. According to section 149 Indian Penal Code

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant ceased membership of unlawful assembly before commission of murder by strangulation.

arguments.claim: Nasir Khan PW 3 evidence shows all accused except Rouf emerged armed, five of six re-entered, but Nawab Ali did not go inside.

anchor.surface_text: So far as this question is concerned, we find that it is in the evidence of Nasir Khan PW 3 that when he and others rushed to the house of Mohd. Shafi on hearing alarm, all the accused except Rouf came out of the house armed with lathis and threatened those present to go away. Five out of the six accused who had come out then went inside the house Nawab Ali, however, did not go inside the house.

arguments.claim: Police Inspector found only six accused inside the house upon arrival; Nawab Ali was not among them.

anchor.surface_text: The Police Inspector, who got the door of the house opened, found only six of the accused present there. The appellant was not among those six accused

arguments.claim: No evidence that Abdul Hamid Khan was strangulated before Nawab Ali left the house; possible strangulation occurred after he ceased to be a member.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence on the record to show that Abdul Hamid Khan was strangulated before Nawab Ali appellant left the house of Mohd. Shafi. Indeed, there is nothing to rule out the possibility of Abdul Hamid Khan having been strangulated after Nawab Ali had left the house of Mohd. Shafi and had thus ceased to be a member of the unlawful assembly.

arguments.qualifiers: no evidence... nothing to rule out

arguments.claim: Section 149 IPC requires the person to be a member of the unlawful assembly at the exact time of commission of the offence for vicarious liability; if ceases membership before, no liability for subsequent acts.

anchor.surface_text: According to section 149 Indian Penal Code, if an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed in prosecution of that object, every person who, at the time of the committing of that offence, is a member of the same assembly, is guilty of that offence. It is, therefore, incumbent upon the prosecution to show that the person concerned was a member of the unlawful assembly at the time of the commission of the offence.

arguments.claim: No liability under section 302/149 IPC can be fastened on Nawab Ali as he ceased to be a member of the unlawful assembly before the offence was committed.

anchor.surface_text: No liability, in our opinion, can be fastened upon Nawab Ali for anything done by the members of the unlawful assembly after he had left the house of Mohd. Shafi and had thus ceased to be a member of the unlawful assembly.

holdings.text: No liability can be fastened upon Nawab Ali for anything done by the members of the unlawful assembly after he had left the house of Mohd. Shafi and had thus ceased to be a member of the unlawful assembly.

anchor.surface_text: No liability, in our opinion. pan be fastened upon Nawab Ali for anything done by the members of the unlawful assembly after he had left the house- of Mohd. Shafi and had thus ceased to be a member of the unlawful assembly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from PW Nasir Khan and police inspection shows appellant did not re-enter house after emerging and was absent when door opened; no evidence strangulation preceded his departure.

holdings.text: It is incumbent upon the prosecution to show that the person concerned was a member of the unlawful assembly at the time of the commission of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, incumbent upon the prosecution to show that die person companycerned was a member of the unlawful assembly at the time of the companymission of the offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Section 149 IPC requiring membership at exact time of offence commission for vicarious liability.

holdings.text: If the person concerned goes away and ceases to be a member of the unlawful assembly before the commission of the offence, no vicarious liability can be fastened upon him under section 149 Indian Penal Code because of any subsequent act done by the other members of the unlawful assembly.

anchor.surface_text: If the person companycerned goes away and ceases to be, a member of the unlawful assembly before the companymission of the offence, numbervicarious liability can be fastened upon him under section 149 Indian Penal Code because of any subsequent act done by the other members of the unlawful assembly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Section 149 IPC to scenario where accused withdraws from assembly prior to overt act causing death.

holdings.text: The conviction of Nawab Ali appellant for the offence under section 302 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code in the circumstances cannot be held to be well founded. We, therefore, accept the appeal of Nawab Ali to the extent of setting aside his conviction under section 302 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code. He is acquitted on that score.

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction of Nawab Ali appellant for the offence under section 302 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code in the circumstances cannot be held to, be well found. We, therefore, accept the appeal of Na

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution failed to prove appellant's membership in unlawful assembly at time of strangulation based on eyewitness and police evidence combined with strict requirements of Section 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, accept the appeal of Nawab Ali to the extent of setting aside his companyviction under section 302 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code. He is acquitted on
